Description: Precancerous skin lesions caused by sun damage; can progress to squamous cell carcinoma
Symptoms: Rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas such as face, scalp, arms; may itch or burn
Medicine: Topical medications like 5-fluorouracil, imiquimod; cryotherapy; photodynamic therapy

Description: Most common type of skin cancer originating in basal cells of the skin's outer layer
Symptoms: Pearly or waxy bump, flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion, bleeding, scabbing, itching
Medicine: Surgery (excision, Mohs surgery), cryotherapy, radiation therapy, topical medications like imiquimod

Description: Non-cancerous skin growths characterized by an overgrowth of keratinocytes
Symptoms: Dark, raised spots (solar lentigines), wart-like growths (seborrheic keratoses), thick, scaly patches (lichen-planus like keratoses)
Medicine: Usually not treated unless for cosmetic reasons; cryotherapy, curettage, laser therapy for removal if desired

Description: Benign skin growth composed of fibrous tissue
Symptoms: Firm, raised bump on the skin, often brownish in color, may dimple when pinched
Medicine: Usually not treated unless for cosmetic reasons; surgical excision if necessary

Description: Aggressive skin cancer arising from melanocytes, the pigment-producing cells
Symptoms: Irregularly shaped moles or spots, changes in color, size, or shape, itching, bleeding, ulceration
Medicine: Surgery (wide excision, sentinel lymph node biopsy), chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, radiation therapy

Description: Common benign moles composed of melanocytes
Symptoms: Small, symmetrical, uniform-colored spots on the skin
Medicine: Usually not treated unless for cosmetic reasons; surgical excision if necessary

Description: Abnormal clusters of blood vessels near the skin's surface
Symptoms: Red or purple bumps, often raised, may bleed or be tender
Medicine: Surgical removal, laser therapy, electrosurgery, cryotherapy
